channel.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
channel.description:
One of the main "worries" about the developments in artificial intelligence is the worry that the intelligent things created will have feelings and thoughts akin to our own.
For this debate, please take the viewpoint that murdering an artificial being which has developed its own thoughts, dreams, aspirations and memories throughout its lifetime is morally the same as murdering a human.
If, instead of the memories being crafted due to the being having experienced the events, the memories are simply implanted into the beings mind, how does it change the moral consequences of killing the being?

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @ItsNateDuh ItsNateDuh
item.description:
@ItsNateDuh wrote:

If you are categorizing ALL “AI” then I believe so? I mean, I drowned my Iphone 5 which had Siri on it, after she drowned a few days passed and my phone was a goner by then so I decided to smash it. So, again yes it is.

Read full topic
item.source: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?

all life is precious.

item.source: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

Something interesting related to this came up in (UK) Channel 4’s Black Mirror Christmas special, “White Christmas”.

[spoiler]“Cookies” are placed inside peoples heads; these cookies then record data about the person’s behaviour and lifestyle. The cookie is then removed and placed into a simulator, and the cookie genuinely believes that it is the original person. It displays emotions, a sense of time, etc. The cookies are then used for a number of inhumane purposes, such as being forced to forever manage their origin’s home to ensure that everything is how they like it, even down to the strength of their toast.

However, the police also use cookies to interrogate suspects, as torture is miraculously easy when you can fast forward time to place someone in confinement for centuries.[/spoiler]

Read full topic
item.source: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @classic mopmans little slave
item.description:
@classic wrote:

t4:

What is inherently wrong with killing anything?

This really is the main question, after all “morals” and words like good and evil depend on the human and our idea of it.

Read full topic

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @whattehp406 whattehp406
item.description:
@whattehp406 wrote:

Is it wrong to kill an animal then? (Fun not survival). It’s the same thing really. A wild lion that’s maybe 8 years old and has feelings and thoughts more advanced than AI. Is it being advanced that means you can live?

Read full topic

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

I think we’ll only be able to discuss this once such artificial lifeforms are created. I mean, the best example of AI I can think of right now are the chatbots…

http://www.frontiernet.net/~wcowart/chatbot.html

Read full topic
item.source: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:1, topic:542449”]If, instead of the memories being crafted due to the being having experienced the events, the memories are simply implanted into the beings mind, how does it change the moral consequences of killing the being?[/quote]Yes, because you can create the exact same AI unit a million times over and it wouldn’t know the difference. If you’ve made it before, you can make it exactly the same again.

Read full topic
item.source: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?

item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

MOPARSCAPE IS SMART ENOUGH TO REWRITE ANY MOTHER LOVING SERIAL KILLING ROBOT INTO DOING THEIR LAUNDRY.

Really if there was any actual worries I’m sure using the off button would do the trick.

Read full topic
item.source: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Elrick:

AI is artificial, which means it has no organic or natural existence. So no, because then technically we shouldn’t be playing videogames that contain violence and have enemies that react to its environment.

Surely the brain is natures complex wiring scheme and chemical signals etc. We don’t have the knowledge, but I bet an artificial reconstruction is at least possible.

Read full topic

item.title: Is it wrong to kill something with artificial thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

I haven’t played Mass Effect for a good 4 years so I’m not sure. And no, not like I Robot, but AIs that believe that they’ve lived a long life and all their memories are real, but infact their memories are all fake and their lives have been short.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Carly wrote:

Are we talking like “I, Robot” AI’s or something else? Because if it does then there should be no problem, or maybe a AI more like the Geth from Mass Effect, centralized host of all shared data and the bodies they use are hosts so it wouldn’t really matter then
